Both images are oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755929/staa200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755929\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=Zn3hKBKR3hx4s6Z5NqeOdILCcWk6Vh2qpukUoE859nfdIaHk34qCyxUZZjzIF5VHVLeDaIDepuMRXE9ZiL6FcZL6aIP2WtuSn9pvtpgtZkoMhLyvJDqoIIjQQ5l80ZSMopcix9H~uf74N5qFoFK1V67wnMrQjryJG1JfhnR1V9B7gbNAYMJtUwSUkY1m8lMtAQf7Ca0nscQKlRydzxa7zkn0ce6B8E~4nwKjLpi0tzWWzHE4QkCfhwolpfe89F9e9Ax3fKZn3HUEheCRik8PaWP9-AlDKQLmu8VDeK9ekbUdyipb6OGFj0f3~7baoYv0jSYGaUE7jLLjaCjixC1ItQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755929&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0104\u22125341. The 1D spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in both <em>R400</em> spectra near an observed wavelength of \u223c8319 \u00c5. We associate this feature with [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], which yields redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 in A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6500\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0259 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 2.18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.43\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(2.42 \\pm 1.10) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755931 id=\"201755931\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 DES J0120\u22125143</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The central red galaxy of this group-scale system, DES J0120\u22125143, has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6030\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0630. There exist three source images, A1, A2, and A3, to the east, north-east, and north\u2013north-west, respectively, of the central red galaxy in the image, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(c)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. In all <em>R400</em> data (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, left-hand panel), there are emission-line features near \u223c8557 \u00c5, which we attribute to [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. The resulting redshifts for the source images are <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for arcs A1, A2, and A3, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"201755933\" scrollto-destination=\"201755933\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=fQiXar4EWGZzpwqQUX26TYsZqBlPMXYS0zP503Wu20p3glYmjAm~bkpcVc3HUGxAsRF9uHFldcmNNlL4PWH~DMWDP4ZjmHlyB7ss5C3p8qaB8q8GJZm7PAEj~qWj~KJm3Ut-Kvavg9UEmm2syP2rjv~Vc8~FELmCR7jYMfxRlpGILeqQLzsGC~0rjblcMK43ZLsAUa50thJd094KbrZIhRbF8IS-YerbTlNdiji3vvjfWz8szqIZBa0yy0AhzN7tPQzLRck9XuXFuESiz8wotcaDDfXYrVRjnOt8ZFmDLO~x4Bh3~JnLv~REdX51Lw9Qmx9jk2vO-ODTpxN-G9mixw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0120\u22125143. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in all three R400 spectra near \u223c8556 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009ii], and from which we obtain redshifts zsource = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in all three <em>R400</em> spectra near \u223c8556 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], and from which we obtain redshifts <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019, \u2018A2\u2019, and \u2018A3\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This lensing system resides in a group environment. There is a counter-image at the south-west that lies nearly on top of the central red lensing galaxy. We were not able to target it for follow-up spectroscopic observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.5238\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0173 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 3.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.51\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(4.46 \\pm 2.78) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755936 id=\"201755936\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 DES J0227\u22124516</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0227\u22124516 is a group-scale lens with the DES photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4300\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0400 and one blue knot (A1) to the south. The system is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(i)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Near wavelengths \u223c 8396 \u00c5, we identify an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line in the <em>R400</em> spectra of the blue knot. This yields source redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.252\u200964\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.000\u200909 (A1) (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, left-hand panel). We used the data from 2016 December to do the redshift determination, because the seeing was much better. We also targeted the faint arc to the east, but the signal-to-noise ratio of the data was too low, and we could not obtain a redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"201755938\" scrollto-destination=\"201755938\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=pvNl-fyCaXDNq1Kzb1K7nsJ3-kXeEnNHo-paP7p1WYbjkHtka6iAav8szou0KOOaIMRXn~LpB4U2Mlt1Oc2ExMHKBj6aRX-8XRnUIa9g7htiX2lPm4YG8A9kUgaOq2YKh63mEGrt3fL~suATR9p1eS~tYbFD8tWhLRE7IL~52dZJpr7eaMoSl6h86afj52qOJwKzz9I9iey63wAjWolzHR3Q1kQOrlmuaVuixgOAgk7rMR5jxPfK5xs-0eMWgaWIYChaa-WzYknqytQ33iLLHAbj0r5KTFUOvz4X7US1zc95ioIZvzxl56aGlcKnGcfd6uWaGNR~Jxo3KVtWpoBKHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0227\u22124516. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the right-hand panel, the feature of interest is labelled \u2018A1\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4347\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0183 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 4.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.28\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(4.32 \\pm 1.32) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755940 id=\"201755940\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-5>5.5 DES J0357\u22124756</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0357\u22124756 is a cluster-scale lens, where the central lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.2570\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240. There is a red arc (A1) to the west, a large red arc (A2) to the south-west, and a red arc (A3) to the south, respectively, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(d)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. In the follow-up <em>R400</em> spectroscopy of all three arcs (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, left-hand panels), we identify an emission line at \u223c7141 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. From this emission line, we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"201755942\" scrollto-destination=\"201755942\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=FYEbWglwK3S6qyOEY4qXvWJuOlqu~5m9CsbzpsZ07yI9pslCTacbGWDIYHhIwfD5c4yP7LDn8-qwTwIWSK-Xyx8Ki46hScgRqR0Oe5CTRKg60srvoWakNID~3ZFzhfNfY6NjAfHNpEkvCRVaNFkAhK9E6JzBq79LXe2ASPgGPQxzU7IGlOPSpqIrAb1xCHdGm8NDUi-wDlxT2tgPn5tp9kNQlYmzRiQk4IzoDX0eYUqP9f4Fb2DUcEeCPr92ZY2TbLsF0VOIEJmVuLDKdIv5tNKAJVwrkXfZhLosl28AaLxXeFw~cFBw-PVvS5anNW2EaKFAQppQHK-peY2RPcUBiA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0357\u22124756. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. Near the observed wavelength of \u223c7142 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009ii] in all three R400 spectra, from which we obtain redshifts of zsource = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, for A1, A2, and A3, respectively, and which are labelled in the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. The image is oriented north up, east left. The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the position designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images to extract the Einstein radius and lens mass.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755942/staa200fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755942\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=vLQH1hf~5hwAJW0jZBWXGerv9lSClCHCIFM726AWGjBZShsjFdWzYM0e9Fu1~HuG6GokDA4ZQjoc1Z6Ui~e-pQbiVKQOPA6yp4r1seT1T3ngtn~knvD4E8AosbI-qJCIuRj~5qx71HDCbN40svN7ypqBv2BRWGoSmhviBlJjVjBkO3lZ1vR-GRKKX6QV2DQElJSo2J~qBNS5uMbMYku4Vun3XM1u4ElJJ3iPiAPJAbogVE9MUcMU85K8grSPaRNjDYp2SSrHkUZHJR9GvfQWbNE7QtpczMweK3hapIpImJIJGwQNwe4cQEPu0D1Gl8h4UsTxJxX7iJNmbTgzwkE2Tw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755942&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0357\u22124756. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. Near the observed wavelength of \u223c7142 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] in all three <em>R400</em> spectra, from which we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, for A1, A2, and A3, respectively, and which are labelled in the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. The image is oriented north up, east left. The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the position designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images to extract the Einstein radius and lens mass.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the location of the lens designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images. Because the goal is to obtain a simple estimate of the lens mass, our goal is to first obtain a reasonable estimate of the Einstein radius.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.2755\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0129 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 9.39\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.91arcsec\u2009to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.38 \\pm 0.36) \\times 10^{13}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755945 id=\"201755945\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-6>5.6 DES J0418\u22125457</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0418\u22125457 is a galaxy-scale lens with the DES photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6130\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0430 and one blue arc (A1) to the north. The system is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(h)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Near a wavelength of \u223c9030 \u00c5, we identify an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line in the <em>R400</em> spectra of both arcs. This yields a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.4236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 (A1) (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, left-hand panel).</p>                        <a id=\"201755947\" scrollto-destination=\"201755947\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=1CA-AMc~FDKNNmDmHKNy0miG-njobXCDSQUB6oOogqSLTWxBNJyQRVdp84Kicxm-kLwi3bO~MGEAIg6nUW9TZz-UdhUgGiaEHh1s69WANB5hUmySobMsdTncPm1iAr86HOeHIKxKVyiTs0WbInmwH8w0-5nP~6a9Vxnf6X4CEv7FxzyMTTdt0mTqGuwSraqutTkkceIg-Q-y6r7zSAQZEOhHlrKkRzeF-inA4-4mRp2JFRafB1whOPn9ioOipbG-o4GE7YD0sxmYlOBCmA8YriUGe2bfDFgK2sJqBhkJ5lsw0VhWGdH5OttCmTc15O1wlPbk4QZF7cCRg6sJKbl-TA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0418\u22125457. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6130\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0430 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 1.97\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.47 \\pm 0.65) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755949 id=\"201755949\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-7>5.7 DES J2113\u22120114</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2113\u22120114 is a galaxy-scale system with two small source images, A1 and A2, which lie to the south-west of the central red galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(e)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4060\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0710. In the <em>R400</em> spectra for A1, we identify emission-line features near \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7361, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5. In both images, we take these emission lines to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 4959, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 5006, respectively, from which we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) for these source images.</p>                        <a id=\"201755951\" scrollto-destination=\"201755951\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=Bv9QpQZPInfytNnAL10dBvJ64RmXQ9mMAoft5yp47fiSaSMVJn41FejWSuxSf0IJd1L3LF0Q9hPOKgZ2ua2YgYu~Ca44X-66Y5SRTTZLDluIqQvoo5DK37lyk1NNMysn9qlPkTyCnn7zv4XjhbZXlhjlvSoCD8TeNqtsgTqx52t4z1frZFmdN8MJOJ94lhosSKrh~ia1PQVjsLERE6eyBu2X1~Exqd82gu20pcJ6xM83cy2k3U2i-lbf2YBA-h1MHZGdgZHpIMx~4fJz4nosoH5NQAGi9WCyAjpXTsZZR-n52E7fbhB5dmccAZetsXNV03~bPzBy4Ub9pFIQPIZmVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2113\u22120114. The 1D R400 spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. A1 presents emission lines near observed wavelengths of \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5, which we conclude correspond to [O\u2009ii], [Ne\u2009iii] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009iii] 4959, and [O\u2009iii]5006, respectively. From these emission lines, we obtain redshifts of zsource = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A2. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755951/staa200fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755951\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=CZEl56OV1H0douKmdvbaGacCUHy0o1o1tEs98Se9QIkUb-sWVQXWjHO8qvwBlSBdSUAV4fqrCWUyKoYcLRdxL0orgO83BCjk~ur9jylhf7sL0FlP5TTIJ~1wUTL6c5Jg9-umjbKijUX4gxFzcjXwr8lnnuIikwIeA6PZN7xvwfKG6FTQqQP4fBZ8mPcB3BvJLCqLTZKpt8MRA985SvTCFna5xuGJipqLkaaFdxCCKMvs4aSsFC5yqMI26-ziagOSNt6DlzKzSzTDcoUhxH4~NJ1Eicrq4WlKMYaWjkkHWPNb7g6nLJjMPlKKqXyYNQCKSZNh6UiSpN3ewADVExzjMQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755951&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2113\u22120114. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. A1 presents emission lines near observed wavelengths of \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5, which we conclude correspond to [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 4959, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]5006, respectively. From these emission lines, we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A2. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4472\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0187 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 1.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.51\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.28 \\pm 1.06) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755953 id=\"201755953\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-8>5.8 DES J2321\u22124630</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2321\u22124630 is a group-scale lens with two central galaxies with DESDM photometric redshifts <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6440\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0250 and 0.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02. There are two small red arcs, A1 and A2, to the east and north-east, respectively, of the central red galaxy. These are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(f)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The <em>R400</em> spectrum of A1 shows prominent emission lines near five different observed wavelengths: \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5, which we identify as C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3346, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], respectively. This gives a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7469\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0014. The <em>R400</em> spectrum of A2 presents a similar pattern for these emission lines: \u223c6391, \u223c6661, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5, which yields a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7479\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0031 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, left-hand panel). There is a possible counter-image to the south-southwest of the lensing galaxy, but it could not be targeted due to its proximity to the central red galaxy and available telescope time.</p>                        <a id=\"201755955\" scrollto-destination=\"201755955\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=FzjbnDTMO-aeRoNyf0Pw-eWLtQFuXxjiex~mUNigqdem4u-AQFG4k9xTo1djglyaUdmHtILN0SWGF1QLpqFqrt2ImSiKg2XungO1xh2hUpQ2RM~QKIIdUT4KYBOe4eqB4YK9ZI~M7lGMjZQg3do3BKqulYEtHrReTxBv-iz15TP~25bQ3EopVJv0kVdAgadVO6OD5BZPA~vikiy~1dKLsDDW7URHoSOwjxVLI1Ae6NU~Gq57OVQOGIz2vUVKeDjKMcbJb9PDgXj3gIITyhEmvLhyg~Yvi8c07SMecJHlcaNYKyo3eimyUWksNeq6RL4SS9OglmAcJHNVdkEOwVql2Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2321\u22124630. The emission lines at four different observed wavelengths in A1 at \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5 are due to C\u2009ii] 2326, [Ne\u2009iv] 2424, and [O\u2009ii], respectively. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for sources A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The emission lines at four different observed wavelengths in A1 at \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5 are due to C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], respectively. A similar pattern of emission lines occurs in A2 at \u223c6391, \u223c6661, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7469\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0014 and 1.7479\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0031 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presence of the Ne emission lines in combination with O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines suggests the possibility that the source is a radio galaxy. Humphrey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) identifies Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> and Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission in <em>z</em>\u223c 2.5 radio galaxies as a potential signature of active galactic nucleus photoionization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The two central galaxies are found in the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> catalogue with redshifts <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6244\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240 and 0.6244\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshifts and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 3.30\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.74\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(3.84 \\pm 1.87) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755958 id=\"201755958\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-9>5.9 DES J2349\u22125113</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113 is a group-scale lens. The central galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.3450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0320, and there are two blue arcs (A1 and A2) to the east and the west. These are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(g)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. Near wavelengths of \u223c8920 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission lines in the <em>R400</em> spectra of both arcs. These yield source redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, left-hand panel). Only after sky subtraction was the line in A2 revealed. Note that A2 appears more extended and much fainter than A1, and, thus, has a much lower signal-to-noise ratio. The faintness of the source, along with a sky line on top of the data (which affected the subtraction), likely reduced the signal in this emission line. The low signal-to-noise ratio for A2 likely contributes to an error in redshift that causes the spectroscopic redshifts to differ beyond their estimated errors.</p>                        <a id=\"201755960\" scrollto-destination=\"201755960\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=uVdyIe-B0vL4vKe4wOuOGPel3Cocxl4deY9iNjg4nQYpMDV8Yw7f01v2kvW-Vl~HFGbpSrOIghJ24kj83qKo6hR1AQ8Ytz-REdGJ6bgiFE7GVgjNIPR~etd7JBxIH0vLEVmntxcpYkXPt1nX4EC~XXTmwD3vVIFvHIPJ8MT-KNCuNAGcnjylEJjZkOQ2moSP5ofWoFbMLPsrMhSfwyrzJfpHDOfTDsIEPDOTrtJBxKRx8LSugGEeYN4crT8D~Ve8s38JqzZWP-oDyuaU5FmskaTcdio0qTFlJiYkfMvOGlwi8NuBXKInWdBHW71arU-MNoHXawR~WQNwJxcnxtEmnQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2349\u22125113. The 1D R400 spectra for A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009ii]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of zsource = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755960/staa200fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=3wqA6Hnh3H7ok0flLyOL0RE5bpls2UQE9DlgXq0chx0uP40UkJitq25xH8kgRbAjgp-t5FtNL3oVDablM2DS-~8Ph5m9H7IdDN1JaihilI4MD979VQyVY1zFUeZ2nrAl2eiWUHM~~0ZmktZE3euGk-Ndv0PZRK5u5kYmtZw1h5Jeb0bls0OK7QjTdGctQOClhGkcmZ496JckxT8IJWm236X4lnHfTf3I7fqZApV5MKnyJyG1OQVJ~rFHX709eFnD2E5tnWjQ2VVoN2ScrlvPK3FaZhrrU-ex7y-Zc8j1o43Ur5T4pPJopfKtfd-UDqesEZ1wqOXy6qbo7MeI9Ox6xA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755960&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of zsource = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755960/staa200fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=3wqA6Hnh3H7ok0flLyOL0RE5bpls2UQE9DlgXq0chx0uP40UkJitq25xH8kgRbAjgp-t5FtNL3oVDablM2DS-~8Ph5m9H7IdDN1JaihilI4MD979VQyVY1zFUeZ2nrAl2eiWUHM~~0ZmktZE3euGk-Ndv0PZRK5u5kYmtZw1h5Jeb0bls0OK7QjTdGctQOClhGkcmZ496JckxT8IJWm236X4lnHfTf3I7fqZApV5MKnyJyG1OQVJ~rFHX709eFnD2E5tnWjQ2VVoN2ScrlvPK3FaZhrrU-ex7y-Zc8j1o43Ur5T4pPJopfKtfd-UDqesEZ1wqOXy6qbo7MeI9Ox6xA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755960&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4094\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0189 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 4.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.71\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(3.77 \\pm 1.42) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755962 id=\"201755962\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION AND SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented new confirmations of galaxy- to cluster-scale strong lenses in Y1 DES data. We first identified candidates in DES data through an investigation of cluster sub-samples, and through catalogue searches of galaxies based on the photometry and proximity of lenses and source images. We then visually inspected these sub-samples to identify 46 candidates for a spectroscopic follow-up. The search was conducted over 1800 deg<sup>2</sup>. We confirmed these systems with spectroscopy from GMOS on the Gemini South telescope. The confirmed sample comprises three galaxy-scale lenses, five group-scale lenses, and one cluster-scale lens. They have been identified through known emission lines, such as Ly\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${}[{\\rm O\\,{\\small II}}]$|</span> 3727. Of particular note is one system, DES J2321\u22124630, in which the presence of Ne emission lines suggests it may be a radio galaxy. For all the confirmed lenses, we provide a rough estimate of the lens mass based on an average of the source image\u2013lens separation from <em>Diehl17</em>. Detailed modelling of these systems can contribute to studies of mass profiles and mass-to-light ratios of early-type galaxies. Poh et\u00a0al. (in preparation) will report the modelling of a subset of these confirmed systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift desert is a key problem in the spectroscopic follow-up of strong lenses. A number of our candidates could not be confirmed or rejected, because they may exist in a redshift range not covered by GMOS spectrographs. One possible solution to this challenge is to seek improved photometric redshift estimations of high-redshift source galaxies. The measurement or prediction of photometric redshifts of distance objects is itself a long-time challenge, largely due to the small number of training sets at high redshift. Another solution is to perform observations in a higher wavelength range \u2013 e.g. in the (near-)infrared with Gemini South\u2019s FLAMINGOS-2 instrument<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> and Paranal Observatory\u2019s Very Large Telescope, which has MUSE and X-Shooter.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search in DES Y1 data and in that of Nord et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) produced many more candidates than feasibly can be followed up with modern spectroscopic observation resources. We confirmed fewer than of those we observed, with an observational strategy that efficiently used the available observing time. The best way to improve chances of positive spectroscopic confirmation in future work is to more accurately and precisely predict strong lens candidates from their imaging. Future searches of DES data are set to take place with more advanced algorithms, stemming from machine learning and citizen science programmes, among others. We expect that these algorithms will provide more flexibility, power, and efficiency in identifying high-quality strong lens candidates.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755966 id=\"201755966\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We are grateful for the extraordinary contributions of our CTIO colleagues and the DES Camera, Commissioning, and Science Verification teams for achieving excellent instrument and telescope conditions that have made this work possible. The success of this project also relies critically on the expertise and dedication of the DES Data Management organization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Kavli Institute of Cosmological Physics at the University of Chicago, the Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics at the Ohio State University, the Mitchell Institute for Fundamental Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&amp;M University, Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos, Funda\u00e7\u00e3o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo \u00e0 Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cient\u00edfico e Tecnol\u00f3gico and the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia e Tecnologia, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, and the Collaborating Institutions in the DES. The DES data management system is supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant Number AST-1138766. The DES participants from Spanish institutions are partially supported by MINECO under grants AYA2012-39559, ESP2013-48274, FPA2013-47986, and Centro de Excelencia Severo Ochoa SEV-2012-0234, some of which include ERDF funds from the European Union.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne National Laboratory, the University of California at Santa Cruz, the University of Cambridge, Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas-Madrid, the University of Chicago, University College London, the DES-Brazil Consortium, the Eidgenoessische Technische Hochschule (ETH) Zurich, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the University of Edinburgh, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Institut de Ci\u00e8ncies de l\u2019Espai (IEEC/CSIC), the Institut de F\u00edsica d\u2019Altes Energies, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the Ludwig-Maximilians Universit\u00e4t and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, the University of Michigan, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, the University of Nottingham, the Ohio State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Portsmouth, the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, the University of Sussex, and Texas A&amp;M University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is based in part on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), the Australian Research Council (Australia), Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (Brazil), and Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog\u00eda e Innovaci\u00f3n Productiva (Argentina). The data were processed using the Gemini <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> package v2.16.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research has made use of NASA\u2019s Astrophysics Data System.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This manuscript has been authored by Fermi Research Alliance, LLC under Contract No. DE-AC02-07CH11359 with the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Office of High Energy Physics. The United States Government retains and the publisher, by accepting the article for publication, acknowledges that the United States Government retains a non-exclusive, paid-up, irrevocable, worldwide license to publish or reproduce the published form of this manuscript, or allow others to do so, for United States Government purposes.</p>                    <h2 class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Observation log for follow-up spectroscopic observations. DES system name is derived from the RA and Dec. position of the lensing object at the centre of the system. The seeing is taken from the Gemini Observation Logs, which keep environmental conditions in 2-h increments: The seeing for each exposure set is the average of the seeing recorded at the time-steps in content-id=\"tblfn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Positions and photometry of objects for each confirmed strong-lensing system. \u2018Object name\u2019 refers to each system (DES system name) or lensed source image (e.g. A1) discussed in the text, in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1 and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span>2\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span>10. All positions (RA, Dec. in J2000) and magnitudes (with <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span>) are drawn from the DESDM database, except for some source images that were too faint to detect or were blended with nearby objects in the automated data reduction process \u2013 these are marked by an asterisk \u2018*\u2019. For these objects, we measured aperture magnitudes via the Graphical Astronomy and Image Analysis software tool (GAIA <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span>2015). Also note that <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> suffers from segmentation issues and so the magnitudes cannot be used for stellar mass estimates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of lensing systems: positions and photometry of lenses and source images.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. content-id=\"tblfn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Positions and photometry of objects for each confirmed strong-lensing system. \u2018Object name\u2019 refers to each system (DES system name) or lensed source image (e.g. A1) discussed in the text, in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span>1 and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span>2\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span>10. All positions (RA, Dec. in J2000) and magnitudes (with <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span>) are drawn from the DESDM database, except for some source images that were too faint to detect or were blended with nearby objects in the automated data reduction process \u2013 these are marked by an asterisk \u2018*\u2019. For these objects, we measured aperture magnitudes via the Graphical Astronomy and Image Analysis software tool (GAIA <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span>2015). Also note that <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> suffers from segmentation issues and so the magnitudes cannot be used for stellar mass estimates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals widget-instance-SiteWideModals\">\n        <div id=\"revealModal\" class=\"reveal-modal\" class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Lensing features of confirmed systems. We show object names for lenses (DES system name) and image labels for sources (e.g. A1), names of spectral features, photometric redshifts of lenses <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, spectroscopic redshifts of sources <em>z</em><sub>source</sub>, an Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub>e</sub> for each system, and the resulting enclosed masses <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub>. The principal spectral features are all emission lines. Redshifts for the lenses are the photometric redshifts drawn from the DESDM database, and they are the first redshifts listed for each system: The uncertainties have been multiplied by 1.5\u00a0times the original estimate, according to the results of S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span>2014), for estimating uncertainties in DES photometric redshift measurement codes. Redshifts of the sources are those measured from a spectroscopic follow-up at Gemini South. All the redshifts for a given system are within sufficient agreement that we measure the enclosed masses using only the spectroscopic redshift of the first source and the source image\u2212lens separation for the system. Instead of providing Einstein radii (see Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation), here we provide rough estimates of the size of lensed features, computed as the weighted average of image-to-lens separation.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>(3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.4)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Lensing features of confirmed systems. We show object names for lenses (DES system name) and image labels for sources (e.g. A1), names of spectral features, photometric redshifts of lenses <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, spectroscopic redshifts of sources <em>z</em><sub>source</sub>, an Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub>e</sub> for each system, and the resulting enclosed masses <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub>. The principal spectral features are all emission lines. Redshifts for the lenses are the photometric redshifts drawn from the DESDM database, and they are the first redshifts listed for each system: The uncertainties have been multiplied by 1.5\u00a0times the original estimate, according to the results of S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span>2014), for estimating uncertainties in DES photometric redshift measurement codes. Redshifts of the sources are those measured from a spectroscopic follow-up at Gemini South. All the redshifts for a given system are within sufficient agreement that we measure the enclosed masses using only the spectroscopic redshift of the first source and the source image\u2212lens separation for the system. Instead of providing Einstein radii (see Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation), here we provide rough estimates of the size of lensed features, computed as the weighted average of image-to-lens separation.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SiteWideModals We describe the observation and confirmation of nine new strong gravitational lenses discovered in Year 1 data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES). We c\" /><meta name=\"citation_xml_url\" content=\"https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-xml/494/1/1308/5716698\" />\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    <link rel=\"canonical\" D Brooks, D L Burke, A Carnero\u00a0Rosell, M Carrasco\u00a0Kind, J Carretero, C E Cunha, L N da\u00a0Costa, C Davis, J De\u00a0Vicente, P Doel, T F Eifler, A E Evrard, E Fernandez, B Flaugher, P L Marshall, P Melchior, F Menanteau, R Miquel, A A Plazas, A K Romer, A Roodman, E S Rykoff, E Sanchez, V Scarpine, R Schindler, M Schubnell, I Sevilla-Noarbe, M Smith, M Soares-Santos, F Sobreira, E <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755873 id=\"201755873\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We describe the observation and confirmation of nine new strong gravitational lenses discovered in Year 1 data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES). We created candidate lists based on (i) galaxy group and cluster samples, and (ii) photometrically selected galaxy samples. We selected 46 candidates through visual inspection and then used the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph<span class=\"small-caps\"><span class=\"small-caps\">(GMOS)</span></span> at the Gemini South telescope to acquire a spectroscopic follow-up of 21 of these candidates. Through an analysis of these spectroscopic follow-up data, we confirmed nine new lensing systems and rejected two candidates, and the analysis was inconclusive on 10 candidates. For each of the confirmed systems, our report measured spectroscopic properties, estimated source image\u2013lens separations, and estimated enclosed masses as well. The sources that we targeted have an <em>i</em>-band surface brightness range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$i_{\\rm SB} \\sim 22\\!-\\!24\\, {\\rm mag}\\,{\\rm arcsec}^{-2}$|</span> and a spectroscopic redshift range of <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> \u223c 0.8\u22122.6. The lens galaxies have a photometric redshift range of <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> \u223c 0.3\u22120.7. The lensing systems range in source image\u2013lens separation from 2 to 9\u2009arcsec and in enclosed mass from 10<sup>12</sup> to 10<sup>13</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: spectroscopic&quot;\">techniques: spectroscopic</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: individual&quot;\">galaxies: individual</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755875 id=\"201755875\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing uniquely demonstrates the interplay between energy and space\u2013time. The light rays from background sources, like galaxies and quasars, are deflected by massive dark matter haloes that are in alignment along an observer\u2019s line of sight, producing highly distorted images of these sources. In this role, strong lensing provides opportunities to study multiple astrophysical and cosmological phenomena \u2013 from the evolution of highly magnified distant galaxies in the early Universe to the matter distribution on the scales of galaxies, as well as cosmic acceleration (seeTreu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">About a thousand lensing systems have been discovered over the last few decades, which we detailed in Nord et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Modern large-scale surveys have the potential to increase the sample by orders of magnitude by virtue of their relatively large depth and sky area. For example, based on selection-function estimates of spectroscopic confirmations (see Nord et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and simulation-based forecasts of future surveys (see Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (DES<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup>; Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is likely to observe more than 2000 galaxy- and cluster-scale lensing systems with arcs, and over a hundred lensed quasars (see Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup>; Ivezic et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) data will contain an order of magnitude more (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>)</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each species of strong lens \u2013 characterized by the scale of the lens, the objects being lensed, and image morphology \u2013 has particular strengths for studying the dark matter, dark energy, cosmic expansion rate, galaxy evolution, and other phenomena. For example, modelling individual lens systems can constrain mass profiles and mass-to-light ratios of early-type galaxies (see Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Modelling the population of galaxy- and group-scale lenses can become constraints on profiles of dark matter haloes in lenses (see More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Double-source-plane lenses \u2013 when there are two sources along the line of sight behind a lens \u2013 can constrain cosmic dark matter and dark energy densities, largely independent of the Hubble constant (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Linder <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).To this date, only a few have been discovered (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Tanaka et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Time-delay cosmology uses variable objects, like lensed quasars and supernovae, to measure the Hubble rate, in a manner largely independent of dark matter and dark energy densities (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Blandford &amp; Narayan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>) or the dark energy equation of state (see Linder <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Recent work by the H0liCOW (H<sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring) collaboration provides constraints on the Hubble constant with a precision that is competitive with other standard cosmological probes (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lenses of different kinds have been the object of targeted searches in DES, including quasar lenses (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), as well as galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses (Nord et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The lensed quasar search is the focus of the STRong-lensing Insights into DES (STRIDES) programme.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> The current work extends this line of DES-wide investigation, with galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses spanning different environments: isolated galaxies, groups, and clusters. Spectroscopic confirmation is time-consuming, yet a critical process for astrophysical and cosmological analyses. While thousands of candidates may be observable with DES, the sample size that is optimized for the aforementioned science goals is constrained by observational resources and the number of systems with science potential.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we describe the spectroscopic confirmation of nine new strong-lensing systems discovered in DES Year 1 (Y1) data. We selected these systems based on the brightness of source galaxies, as well as on the potential for modelling the system \u2013 i.e. morphological simplicity and potential to examine the mass profile of the underlying dark matter halo. We first created lists of candidates based on (i) samples of galaxy groups and clusters, and (ii) photometrically selected galaxies \u2013 totaling \u223c9500 candidates. We then visually inspected an image of each candidate system. This led to the selection of 46 candidates, and we performed a spectroscopic follow-up on 21 of those. We then analysed the spectroscopic data to determine the redshifts of the sources in those lenses to discern if the systems are indeed strong lenses. We describe in more detail the lens candidate search process in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we focus on nine systems (shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) that show pieces of evidence \u2013 morphology, photometry, and spectroscopy \u2013 of strong gravitational lensing: Three of the systems are galaxy-scale lenses, five are group-scale lens, and one is a cluster-scale lens. All of them are newly discovered and confirmed objects. Detailed mass models of a subset of the confirmed systems will be presented in a separate paper (see Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                        <a id=\"201755882\" scrollto-destination=\"201755882\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=RE1hFlBmbBlPwPwUeoxAAiqKoBurBwW4gohu10B7dZWCIdFnHhoe08zBcM~UbraUbwVi1bwQlCOBY8W1Khxo2yUcOGoQfBu~Lk~C4qo3Amn-s03uE1rgsyCXPBKMYrOL-1QKuscqFlClyxPX28vwmTyxLWWB5hmB6yMWorMgtROnKuKf7E99vlH3-~X9aFLJuPH~Dz4kD9-GSCRFEzumKsY6ZtRHW3BdJrHvc9Dy1KnAztFgLgG09tki1vYh9P8n~O89HC-32vB6Zy5WjTyZkzN9FXQfsns0aJsF0KMnf7L5aLXjf68BsHLMlouRlw2xiFnLqt-uoPQfpzo5Ff4wXA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour co-add DES images of the nine confirmed lensing systems described in this work: (a) DES J0041\u22124155, (b) DES J0104\u22125341, (c) DES J0120\u22125143, (d) DES J0227\u22124516, (e) DES J0357\u22124756, (f) DES J0418\u22125457, (g) DES J2113\u22120114, (h) DES J2321\u22124630, and (i) DES J2349\u22125113.
