The lensing features targeted for spectroscopy are indicated by the letters. Refer to Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> for additional images of the candidates and their spectroscopic information.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=RE1hFlBmbBlPwPwUeoxAAiqKoBurBwW4gohu10B7dZWCIdFnHhoe08zBcM~UbraUbwVi1bwQlCOBY8W1Khxo2yUcOGoQfBu~Lk~C4qo3Amn-s03uE1rgsyCXPBKMYrOL-1QKuscqFlClyxPX28vwmTyxLWWB5hmB6yMWorMgtROnKuKf7E99vlH3-~X9aFLJuPH~Dz4kD9-GSCRFEzumKsY6ZtRHW3BdJrHvc9Dy1KnAztFgLgG09tki1vYh9P8n~O89HC-32vB6Zy5WjTyZkzN9FXQfsns0aJsF0KMnf7L5aLXjf68BsHLMlouRlw2xiFnLqt-uoPQfpzo5Ff4wXA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour co-add DES images of the nine confirmed lensing systems described in this work: (a) DES J0041\u22124155, (b) DES J0104\u22125341, (c) DES J0120\u22125143, (d) DES J0227\u22124516, (e) DES J0357\u22124756, (f) DES J0418\u22125457, (g) DES J2113\u22120114, (h) DES J2321\u22124630, and (i) DES J2349\u22125113. Images are oriented north up, east left, and are 1 \u00d7 1 arcmin2 in area. The colour images are composites of the g, r, and i bands. The lensing features targeted for spectroscopy are indicated by the letters. Refer to Figs\u00a02\u201310 for additional images of the candidates and their spectroscopic information.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755882/staa200fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755882\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=IdEvnIAR~vR0WvqN4SeQIj-XXMaeYlpiCMebpTeaCJVU13jQr-Pzj8-YHWApErhVXBXfLmh8RCjOd5y4NDedgbIkIy-WDFjWeOIaLJE4T5i~-myICx7JoUPZmM2e-AcFg~odSzxinF9qSiGJ58g0HCQ7iOfnC0Lq252UjORcebMfXsJcbwDX6ac2eeBOZlALGgd1ZDgmPE798xIDYku6NigK~pBKOZ16JGsMf0V5-~hTnT7D7EMNYZnAmMQw639LxQARZSiL2BpWj6NrkeMo8CJo5pJvfIoIyODrvRZ7SQcbbX4i4g70fL7jDErRk8237pLHt5fvgRuszfFKj4Nchg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755882&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour co-add DES images of the nine confirmed lensing systems described in this work: (a) DES J0041\u22124155, (b) DES J0104\u22125341, (c) DES J0120\u22125143, (d) DES J0227\u22124516, (e) DES J0357\u22124756, (f) DES J0418\u22125457, (g) DES J2113\u22120114, (h) DES J2321\u22124630, and (i) DES J2349\u22125113. Images are oriented north up, east left, and are 1 \u00d7 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> in area. The colour images are composites of the <em>g, r</em>, and <em>i</em> bands. The lensing features targeted for spectroscopy are indicated by the letters. Refer to Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> for additional images of the candidates and their spectroscopic information.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper has the following structure. We describe the DES Y1 data in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. We discuss the search for lens candidates in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> and then the follow-up spectroscopic observations and analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. We present the nine confirmed systems and their properties in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We then conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. The AB system is used for all magnitudes. A Planck \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology with spatially flat priors is assumed: \u03a9<sub>M</sub> = 0.308, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.692, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0=67.8\\, {\\rm km\\, s^{-1}}\\, {\\rm Mpc}^{-1}$|</span> (see Planck Collaboration XIII <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755884 id=\"201755884\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DES YEAR 1 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES covers \u223c5000 deg<sup>2</sup> in a deep, wide-field survey of the southern Galactic Cap in five optical filters (<em>grizY</em>). It extends to a depth of <em>i</em> \u223c 24 mag at a 10<em>\u03c3</em> detection threshold and a 27 deg<sup>2</sup> supernova survey across 10 fields \u2013 two deep and eight shallow. The depth in the repeated supernova area is typically two magnitudes deeper than the wide-field survey. The survey is undertaken with the Dark Energy Camera (DECam; Flaugher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which is a 3 deg<sup>2</sup> CCD mosaic camera mounted on the BLANCO 4-m telescope at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory<span class=\"small-caps\">(CTIO)</span> in the Chilean Andes. The DES footprint is observable between August and mid-February. Each year, DES is allocated \u223c105 nights, and it has now completed all five-and-a-half years of planned observations. Because of its large field of view and red-sensitive CCDs, DECam is particularly suited to high-redshift survey work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this work, we use the Year One First Annual (Y1A1) internal collaboration release of the DES data. The survey and operations are described in Diehl et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The data in the Y1A1 release were acquired between 2013 August 15 and 2014 February 9. These data cover \u223c1840 deg<sup>2</sup> to a median 10<em>\u03c3</em> point-source depth calculated with <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span>\u2019s fixed-aperture magnitudes (<span class=\"monospace\">MAG APER</span>), with 1.95-arcsec apertures, of 24.19, 23.85, 23.25, 22.55, and 21.20 in the <em>g, r, i, z</em>, and <em>Y</em> bands, respectively (see Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The reduction of the images from DES Y1 data was performed by the DES data management (DESDM) team (see Morganson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). After detrending, the single-epoch images were combined into \u2018co-add tiles\u2019 after first being calibrated and background-subtracted. The tiles are co-add images comprising one to five exposures in each of the five wavelength bandpasses. On average, in each tile, the coverage comprised 3.5 exposures. Each co-add tile has dimensions 0.73 \u00d7 0.73\u2009deg<sup>2</sup>, which are defined to cover the full footprint of DES homogeneously. The final survey depth is deeper than the Y1A1 release, which consists of 3707 co-add tiles. This footprint covers two non-contiguous regions: One overlaps the deeply imaged Stripe 82 (see Jiang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) from SDSS (see York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Abazajian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and the other overlaps the area that is covered by the South Pole Telescope (SPT; Carlstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). More details of the reductions are available in Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) image detection software is used for catalogue source detection. It is deployed in a double-image mode, and for the detection image, it uses the <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> detection image, which is constructed from the combination of the <em>r</em>-, <em>i-</em>, and <em>z</em>-band images. Positional and photometric data of all the objects in this study (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) come from this object catalogue. While MAG APER is used for the measures of depth in the Y1A1 catalogue release, in this work, we use the magnitude measure, <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span>, to perform catalogue searches for lens candidates.</p>                        <a id=\"201755889\" scrollto-destination=\"201755889\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of lensing systems: positions and photometry of lenses and source images.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. content-id=\"tblfn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Positions and photometry of objects for each confirmed strong-lensing system. \u2018Object name\u2019 refers to each system (DES system name) or lensed source image (e.g. A1) discussed in the text, in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. All positions (RA, Dec. in J2000) and magnitudes (with <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span>) are drawn from the DESDM database, except for some source images that were too faint to detect or were blended with nearby objects in the automated data reduction process \u2013 these are marked by an asterisk \u2018*\u2019. For these objects, we measured aperture magnitudes via the Graphical Astronomy and Image Analysis software tool (GAIA <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Also note that <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> suffers from segmentation issues and so the magnitudes cannot be used for stellar mass estimates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201755889\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of lensing systems: positions and photometry of lenses and source images.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. content-id=\"tblfn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Positions and photometry of objects for each confirmed strong-lensing system. \u2018Object name\u2019 refers to each system (DES system name) or lensed source image (e.g. A1) discussed in the text, in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. All positions (RA, Dec. in J2000) and magnitudes (with <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> derived from <span class=\"small-caps\">SourceExtractor</span>) are drawn from the DESDM database, except for some source images that were too faint to detect or were blended with nearby objects in the automated data reduction process \u2013 these are marked by an asterisk \u2018*\u2019. For these objects, we measured aperture magnitudes via the Graphical Astronomy and Image Analysis software tool (GAIA <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Also note that <span class=\"monospace\">Mag_Auto</span> suffers from segmentation issues and so the magnitudes cannot be used for stellar mass estimates.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201755889\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755890 id=\"201755890\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 LENS SEARCH</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To identify candidates in DES Y1 data, we used (i) samples of galaxy clusters selected via DES data or via SPT data, and (ii) galaxies selected based on photometry. A number of expert scanners visually inspected candidates in search of visually compelling evidence (e.g. morphology, colour, brightness) that the systems would be useful for mass modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search method used to create candidate lists for visual inspection primarily selects for blue or red source galaxies near single galaxies or within groups or clusters of galaxies. Searches of 7328 optically selected galaxy clusters \u2013 found with the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> algorithm (Rykoff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) \u2013 as well as a selection of galaxies from the redMaGiC catalogue (Rozo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Cawthon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) yielded 374 candidates in the DES Y1 footprint. This is described in section\u00a03.3 of Diehl et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), which will from here on be referred to as <em>Diehl17</em>. A third search of SPT galaxy clusters yielded 66 more candidates (described in section 3.1 of <em>Diehl17</em>). Candidates from searches described elsewhere in <em>Diehl17</em> added 88 more. Some candidates were the result of serendipitous discovery, and those were not described in <em>Diehl17</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The combined searches resulted in a list of 112 candidate systems. A sample of 46 candidates were selected on the bases of (i) science cases (e.g. the potential for modelling the dark matter halo of the lens itself), and (ii) objects that are already targeted by other follow-up efforts (e.g. some SPT clusters). Note that the ranking discussed in <em>Diehl17</em> is purely based on how likely an object is to be a lens (not on how easy it would be to follow up).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We cross-checked both our follow-up candidate sample and the full Y1A1 footprint against the Master Lens Database (MLDB; last updated 2018 February 2), which contains 674 candidates and confirmed systems. None of the candidates we observed during our follow-up for this paper is found in MLDB.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are two areas in the DES Y1A1 footprint: one overlaps with SPT and the other overlaps with SDSS Stripe 82. From MLDB, 202 lenses are within the Y1A1 footprint \u2013 28 in the SPT area and 174 in Stripe82 area. Those in the SPT area have sufficiently high redshift to not be visible within wavelengths observed by DES. Those in the Stripe82 area were already discovered and are not within our follow-up sample.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755896 id=\"201755896\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 SPECTROSCOPIC FOLLOW-UP AT GEMINI/GMOS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we aim to report the spectroscopic evidence for strong gravitational lensing in a sample of candidates that were selected through visual scans of images. We identified 46 candidates during the lens search, from which we chose the 21 candidates that are most suitable for a follow-up with spectroscopic observations and analysis. The bases for this downselection are the (i) brightness of source galaxies, and (ii) suitability of system for observation (e.g. mask alignment). We measure the spectroscopic redshifts of source galaxies to determine if they are larger than the putative lens redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We require a wide spectral range to search for patterns of narrow emission lines. We expect some sources to be late-type emission-line galaxies. With these, we look for several features, such as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and H\u03b2 to <em>z</em> \u223c 1.0; H\u03b4, H\u03b3, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> to <em>z</em> \u223c 1.7; and Ly\u03b1 in the range <em>z</em> \u223c 2.7\u22127.2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of the Gemini Large and Long Program (GS-2015B-LP-5 and GS-2016B-LP-5),<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> we used the multi-object mode of the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph <span class=\"small-caps\">(<span class=\"small-caps\">gmos</span></span>; Hook et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) at the Gemini South telescope for spectroscopic observations of our candidates. This proposal includes the goal of creating a spectroscopic sample of red galaxies for photometric redshift calibration. Below, we describe the observing strategy and the reductions of the spectroscopic data.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755900 id=\"201755900\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Observing strategy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We used the following procedure for planning the follow-up. For the purposes of planning the follow-up,wefirst ranked 21 candidates by their <em>i</em>-band surface brightness, which is calculated using an aperture that is2 arcsec in diameter. We defined three sets of gratings and exposure times. The combinations depend on these surface brightness classes: For objects with surface brightness <em>i</em><sub>SB</sub> &lt; 23, we integrate for1\u00a0h in the <em>R400</em> grating; for objects with surface brightness 23 &lt; <em>i</em><sub>SB</sub> &lt; 24, we integrate for 3.7\u00a0h in the <em>R400</em> grating and then for 1\u00a0h in the <em>B600</em> grating; for objects with surface brightness <em>i</em><sub>SB</sub> &gt; 24, we integrate for 1\u00a0h in the <em>B600</em> grating. See Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> for details of the observations that were performed.</p>                        <a id=\"201755902\" scrollto-destination=\"201755902\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopic observation log.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>DES system name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"small-caps\">ut</span> date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Grating<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Integration time<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Observation log for follow-up spectroscopic observations. DES system name is derived from the RA and Dec. position of the lensing object at the centre of the system. The seeing is taken from the Gemini Observation Logs, which keep environmental conditions in 2-h increments: The seeing for each exposure set is the average of the seeing recorded at the time-steps in the Gemini environmental logs that bracket the observations of interest.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow .\u00a0</span></th><th>Grating<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Integration time<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DES J0041\u22124155\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 11, 12\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>0.93/1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.11/1.47\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0104\u22125341\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 11\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.87/1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.83/1.55\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0120\u22125143\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 11\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.42\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0227\u22124516\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 8, 9\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.67/1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.83/\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0227\u22124516\u00a0</td><td>2016 Dec 1, 5\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00/1.00\u00a0</td><td>0.73/0.63\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0357\u22124756\u00a0</td><td>2015 Dec 8\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>0.93/1.\u00a0</td><td>0.87/0.81\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J0418\u22125457\u00a0</td><td>2016 Dec 1, 3\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>/<em>B600</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00/1.00\u00a0</td><td>0.8/0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2113\u22120114\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 11\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.83\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2321\u22124630\u00a0</td><td>2015 Oct 12\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td><td>1.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2349\u22125113\u00a0</td><td>2015 Dec 7\u00a0</td><td><em>R400</em>\u00a0</td><td>1.00\u00a0</td><td>0.76\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Observation log for follow-up spectroscopic observations. DES system name is derived from the RA and Dec. position of the lensing object at the centre of the system. The seeing is taken from the Gemini Observation Logs, which keep environmental conditions in 2-h increments: The seeing for each exposure set is the average of the seeing recorded at the time-steps in the Gemini environmental logs that bracket the observations of interest.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201755902\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We mostly performed 1-h observations, which allowed us to obtain a sufficient signal in the cases for which a lens could be confirmed in that amount of time. More than 1 h of integration would be unlikely to yield an enough additional signal-to-noise ratio to warrant spending the time. In the event that a clear signal did not appear during the prescribed observations, we chose to not perform additional observations or longer integration times for any system. We made this decision to conserve telescope time and to maximize the number of strong-lens-system confirmations. Moreover, consistent integration times across the observation fields incur consistent depths \u2013 a requirement for the photo-<em>z</em> calibration targets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We centred each field\u2019s mask on the lens of the candidate system, and we placed slits on the images of the sources. In some cases, we shifted the centre of the field to accommodate a suitable guide star. We also rotated the slit mask (i.e. rotated the position angle of the system) to include as many source targets as possible. Slits were first placed on as many of the source images as possible. Then, for the calibration of DES photometric redshifts, the unused slits (about 40) were placed on galaxy targets. While the slit lengths varied, all the slits were 1 arcsec in width. This setting accommodated both the object and the amount of sky sufficient for reliable background subtraction. In some cases, the slits were tilted to maximize the flux captured from an extended source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To obtain spectra of objects with redshift <em>z</em> &lt; 1.7 and wavelength coverage <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 5000\\!-\\!10\\, 000$|</span> \u00c5, we use the <em>R400</em> grating in conjunction with the <em>GG455</em> filter. For spectra of objects with redshift <em>z</em> &gt; 2 and within the wavelength range 3250\u20136250 \u00c5, we use the <em>B600</em> grating without a filter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For an observing sequence with a 1-h science integration, we first took a pair of half-hour 900-s science exposures. Then, we used a Quartz-Halogen lamp to take a flat-field and a Quartz-Halogen lamp to take a calibration spectrum. To cover the gap between the CCDs, we then shifted to a different central wavelength. Finally, we repeated this sequence in reverse order. For the 3.7-h science integration, we instead used 840-s science exposures and repeated the above sequence 16\u00a0times. We facilitated the removal of cosmic rays by dividing the integration time into multiple exposures. We binned the data 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02, which gave effective dispersions of 1.0 and 1.5 \u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>-1</sup> for the <em>B600</em> and <em>R400</em> gratings, respectively.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755907 id=\"201755907\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Spectroscopic reductions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We used the Gemini\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> package v1.13.1<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> for <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> v2.16 to reduce the exposures. Some of the Gemini\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> tasks were modified to provide additional flexibility in the data reduction. First, for each wavelength dither in a given system, we use the <span class=\"monospace\">gsflat</span> task to process (including bias subtraction) the flat-field. We then use these processed flat images and <span class=\"monospace\">gsreduce</span> to reduce each science exposure. Then, the two exposures are combined with <span class=\"monospace\">gemcombine</span>. We then use the <span class=\"monospace\">gswavelength</span> and <span class=\"monospace\">gstransform</span> tasks to perform wavelength calibration and transformation on each dither.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Then, we co-add a pair of dithers on the new common wavelength scale, which eliminates CCD chip gaps. We use <span class=\"monospace\">gsextract</span> (which calls the <span class=\"monospace\">apall</span> task) to perform sky subtraction and one-dimensional (1D) spectral extraction. We use night sky lines from the science spectra to add calibration lines to the 5500\u20136400 \u00c5 wavelength range. We modified the canonical reduction process by taking the log of the fluxes in the calibration spectra to enable simultaneous automated identification of both the strong lines above 7000 \u00c5 and the weaker lines below that. For improved interactive flexibility in this part of the reduction, <span class=\"monospace\">gswavelength</span> and <span class=\"monospace\">gsextract</span> were modified to allow wavelength calibration and 1D spectral extraction, respectively, for selected individual slits, as needed. Finally, we use the <span class=\"monospace\">emsao</span> task within the <span class=\"monospace\">rvsao</span><span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> package (Kurtz &amp; Mink <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) for feature identification and redshift estimation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755910 id=\"201755910\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SAMPLE OF CONFIRMED LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We confirmed that 9 of the 21 observed candidate systems are indeed strong-lensing systems, and we rejected two candidates. The remaining 10 were not confirmed, and spectroscopic analysis was inconclusive for those candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the two rejected systems contains a foreground star-forming galaxy, and the other contains a background group (rather than the apparent multiply lensed red galaxy). The systems that we failed to confirm exhibit promising lensing features, but the sources have no discernible continuum emission, no spectral features, or both. The measurements of spectroscopic features are too low signal-to-noise ratios with the integration times in our observing programme, or they have redshifts that are outside the range of the optical observations in our observing programme (i.e. in the redshift desert). We list the rejected and inconclusive systems in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201755913\" scrollto-destination=\"201755913\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inconclusive and rejected candidates.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Object name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, for each observed lensing system, we list the positions and photometry of the candidate lens and source(s). The sample is composed of three galaxy-scale lenses (b, f, g), five group-scale lenses (a, c, d, h, i), and one cluster-scale lens (e).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we provide details of each system \u2013 the important spectral features, the measured redshifts, and simple mass estimates. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> show the reduced 1D spectra and a cut-out of the field centred on the central lensing object, including labelled source positions for each system.</p>                        <a id=\"201755916\" scrollto-destination=\"201755916\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=Fdhaj5k~Imi0pOdRlwbysZM2-P4rNbxVcdSoc43bTSlqw-8a~GN41OpQndSCf2OxjH~ZPR6XZcIq7t67V26-2qMx5csDwkBEQhFI7edxTxoTiry1Lq6X5VesCF2bJyeEBcGmzefHIhCW-GEzulZVDNpK-xuytqWPwRqnqxbJdsAGvEs75YFoCNY00VWREbbWMlfNz0xgEemcMQI4krqx1JECB3dEp6JRyPZ0o0OOak3L-moiMUAdDWgAWAtm3aQ7bELiFsOrlZ4hiaH~gDN6MdYDG3fKQ9NdGdq1qwFIp237n6MFqv2UuZ87Q7Xh9mD7lKVQuBEijYMJE-BPf6vzzA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0041\u22124155. The 1D spectra for A1, A2, and A3 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines near the same observed wavelength \u223c4329 \u00c5 in all three B600 spectra. We assign these features to be Ly\u03b1, which gives redshifts of zsource = 2.5619\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 2.5618\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 2.5616\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755916/staa200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755916\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=EsfNO86B1M906xa6ZjBuTpw1GC9mjCBUBdKkYvlPaQ~muX4qOimXvvUQG9XUw7mT988uO0wNDLjSGPfVkhZy0WgUCWc4lRSPwas1WY6MY4VRP-QX1VYbR5kq0TmWxZ5~GCr0snBe4dh6ysSy2KeaHT08XcFqZJ72sF-LXeVAk00bem0nh1C~LUr8NZRpKN6e0Z6wQaUfALTZnTRKBjDL4J6f4~ZWxB7JTLXta4jcXezqZQNpD4FhXWSX67lYETDRR5zeLzPzzBi3EOafUZRRYeVotZIiMkWOgWpjVK4Y~c2Q9SJinZKodoPiy~slp2wZFPZvwOTHpsktyCrL-l-ZsQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755916&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0041\u22124155. The 1D spectra for A1, A2, and A3 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines near the same observed wavelength \u223c4329 \u00c5 in all three <em>B600</em> spectra. We assign these features to be Ly\u03b1, which gives redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 2.5619\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 2.5618\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 2.5616\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=Fdhaj5k~Imi0pOdRlwbysZM2-P4rNbxVcdSoc43bTSlqw-8a~GN41OpQndSCf2OxjH~ZPR6XZcIq7t67V26-2qMx5csDwkBEQhFI7edxTxoTiry1Lq6X5VesCF2bJyeEBcGmzefHIhCW-GEzulZVDNpK-xuytqWPwRqnqxbJdsAGvEs75YFoCNY00VWREbbWMlfNz0xgEemcMQI4krqx1JECB3dEp6JRyPZ0o0OOak3L-moiMUAdDWgAWAtm3aQ7bELiFsOrlZ4hiaH~gDN6MdYDG3fKQ9NdGdq1qwFIp237n6MFqv2UuZ87Q7Xh9mD7lKVQuBEijYMJE-BPf6vzzA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0041\u22124155. The 1D spectra for A1, A2, and A3 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines near the same observed wavelength \u223c4329 \u00c5 in all three B600 spectra. We assign these features to be Ly\u03b1, which gives redshifts of zsource = 2.5619\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 2.5618\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 2.5616\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755916/staa200fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755916\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=EsfNO86B1M906xa6ZjBuTpw1GC9mjCBUBdKkYvlPaQ~muX4qOimXvvUQG9XUw7mT988uO0wNDLjSGPfVkhZy0WgUCWc4lRSPwas1WY6MY4VRP-QX1VYbR5kq0TmWxZ5~GCr0snBe4dh6ysSy2KeaHT08XcFqZJ72sF-LXeVAk00bem0nh1C~LUr8NZRpKN6e0Z6wQaUfALTZnTRKBjDL4J6f4~ZWxB7JTLXta4jcXezqZQNpD4FhXWSX67lYETDRR5zeLzPzzBi3EOafUZRRYeVotZIiMkWOgWpjVK4Y~c2Q9SJinZKodoPiy~slp2wZFPZvwOTHpsktyCrL-l-ZsQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755916&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0041\u22124155. The 1D spectra for A1, A2, and A3 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines near the same observed wavelength \u223c4329 \u00c5 in all three <em>B600</em> spectra. We assign these features to be Ly\u03b1, which gives redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 2.5619\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 2.5618\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 2.5616\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We estimate the enclosed mass <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub> of the lensing system under the assumption of a singular isothermal sphere mass profile (Narayan &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nM_{\\rm enc}= \\frac{c^2}{4G} \\theta _{\\rm e}^2 \\left(\\frac{D_{\\rm L} D_{\\rm S}}{D_{\\rm L S}}\\right),\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>c</em> is the speed of light, <em>G</em> is Newton\u2019s gravitational constant, <em>\u03b8</em><sub>e</sub> is the Einstein radius, and <em>D</em> is the angular diameter distance. In particular, <em>D</em><sub>L</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>S</sub>, and <em>D</em><sub>LS</sub> are the angular diameter distances to the lens, to the source, and between the lens and the source, respectively. We use the source image\u2013lens separation (calculated in <em>Diehl17</em>) as an approximation for the Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub>. It is measured by taking the average of the distances between a targeted source image and the selected central lensing galaxy. This estimate of the Einstein radius is only accurate to a factor of 2, and it is an overestimate for cases in which only the brightest source image is used to approximate the radius.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the standard deviation of the distances summed in quadrature with the pixel scale of DECam (0.263\u2009arcsec\u2009pixel<sup>-1</sup>) to estimate the uncertainty in this distance. The angular diameter distances depend only on redshifts of the objects and on cosmological parameters. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> summarizes key information for all the confirmed systems \u2013 spectral features, photometric redshifts of lenses, spectroscopic redshifts of sources, source image\u2212lens separation, and enclosed masses. This strategy is similar to that used in the Sloan Bright Arc Survey (SBAS; e.g. Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"201755919\" scrollto-destination=\"201755919\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>(3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.4)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Lensing features of confirmed systems. We show object names for lenses (DES system name) and image labels for sources (e.g. A1), names of spectral features, photometric redshifts of lenses <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, spectroscopic redshifts of sources <em>z</em><sub>source</sub>, an Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub>e</sub> for each system, and the resulting enclosed masses <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub>. The principal spectral features are all emission lines. Redshifts for the lenses are the photometric redshifts drawn from the DESDM database, and they are the first redshifts listed for each system: The uncertainties have been multiplied by 1.5\u00a0times the original estimate, according to the results of S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), for estimating uncertainties in DES photometric redshift measurement codes. Redshifts of the sources are those measured from a spectroscopic follow-up at Gemini South. All the redshifts for a given system are within sufficient agreement that we measure the enclosed masses using only the spectroscopic redshift of the first source and the source image\u2212lens separation for the system. Instead of providing Einstein radii (see Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation), here we provide rough estimates of the size of lensed features, computed as the weighted average of image-to-lens separation.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201755919\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" J0227\u22124516\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.4347\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0183\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span 5007\u00a0</td><td>0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u00a0</td><td>(1.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.1)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3868, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 4959, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 5007\u00a0</td><td>0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2321\u22124630\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>0.6427\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0363\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1\u00a0</td><td>C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3346, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.7469\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0014\u00a0</td><td>3.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>(3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.9)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2\u00a0</td><td>C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3346, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.7479\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0031\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DES J2349\u22125113\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>0.4094\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0189\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A1\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7\u00a0</td><td>(3.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.4)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>12</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A2\u00a0</td><td>[O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td><td>1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td><td>...\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Lensing features of confirmed systems. We show object names for lenses (DES system name) and image labels for sources (e.g. A1), names of spectral features, photometric redshifts of lenses <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, spectroscopic redshifts of sources <em>z</em><sub>source</sub>, an Einstein radius <em>\u03b8</em><sub>e</sub> for each system, and the resulting enclosed masses <em>M</em><sub>enc</sub>. The principal spectral features are all emission lines. Redshifts for the lenses are the photometric redshifts drawn from the DESDM database, and they are the first redshifts listed for each system: The uncertainties have been multiplied by 1.5\u00a0times the original estimate, according to the results of S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), for estimating uncertainties in DES photometric redshift measurement codes. Redshifts of the sources are those measured from a spectroscopic follow-up at Gemini South. All the redshifts for a given system are within sufficient agreement that we measure the enclosed masses using only the spectroscopic redshift of the first source and the source image\u2212lens separation for the system. Instead of providing Einstein radii (see Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation), here we provide rough estimates of the size of lensed features, computed as the weighted average of image-to-lens separation.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201755919\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We combine uncertainties from the measurements of the distances and source image\u2212lens separation to estimate frequentist uncertainties for the enclosed mass. According to the prescription of S\u00e1nchez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) for photometric redshifts in DES, the photometric redshift uncertainties have been multiplied by a factor of 1.5. The spectroscopic redshift uncertainties are the result of a sum in quadrature of (i) the uncertainty in wavelength calibration, and (ii) the uncertainty in the redshift determination from the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> function <span class=\"monospace\">emsao</span>. These spectroscopic redshift uncertainties are then propagated to the angular diameter distances.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass uncertainty results from the sum in quadrature of uncertainties from the source image\u2212lens separation, and the angular diameter distances. The uncertainty on each angular diameter distance scales with the redshift error, which falls in the range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 0.008\\!-\\!0.19{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> for spectroscopic redshifts and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 3.2\\!-\\!17.5{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> for lens redshifts. The uncertainty in the source image\u2212lens separation, which falls in the range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 6\\!-\\!22{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, is purely statistical. This results in mass uncertainties in the range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 25\\!-\\!80{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>\u00a0summarizes the lensing features for the confirmed systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A subset of the systems have sources with multiple, detailed images, making them amenable to detailed modelling, which will be performed in a separate paper (Poh et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755923 id=\"201755923\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 DES J0041\u22124155</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0041\u22124155 is a group-scale system. The largest central red galaxy has a DESDM photometric redshift of <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.7160\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0310. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(a)</a>, there are three prominent blue-pink arcs, A1, A2, and A3, to the north, north-west, and west, respectively, of the lensing galaxy. The right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> also displays these arcs. We identify emission lines in the follow-up <em>B600</em> spectroscopy of the three images near the observed wavelength of \u223c4329 \u00c5 in all three spectra (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, left-hand panel). When we account for the absence of spectral features in the <em>R400</em> spectra, as well as the photometric redshift of the lens galaxy, we can assign spectral features to be Ly\u03b1. This then gives redshifts <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 2.5619\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 2.5618\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 2.5616\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identified no counter-images. In the <em>R400</em> spectrum for A1, there is an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line at \u223c6620 \u00c5 (not shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), which corresponds to a redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.7761\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.000\u200907 of a foreground object. This is clearly visible as a bluer galaxy superimposed on A1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.7317\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0198 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 7.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.50\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.74 \\pm 0.47) \\times 10^{13}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755927 id=\"201755927\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 DES J0104\u22125341</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0104\u22125341 is a galaxy-scale lensing system. The red lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6790\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0220, and there are two relatively red arcs to the west and south, labelled A1 and A2, respectively, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(b)</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We identify strong emission lines for A1 and A2 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, left-hand panel) in both <em>R400</em> spectra near an observed wavelength of \u223c8319 \u00c5. In the absence of features in the <em>B600</em> spectra, we associate this feature with [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], yielding redshifts <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. We see no counter-images for this source.</p>                        <a id=\"201755929\" scrollto-destination=\"201755929\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=DruiBWKF9VA8Ccf0RRtV1rJzQlvEpbIyim53S51htqjWgIDeADIcM1bnpVSmTF160lODYV2nPp54ArU5UKS6mRSEsIgREAKmH~8htzIZEibVAGuVjQiA8E5jkMXPgd2GOTkEwuM4Y-F-~-CGgHyi-hcTausL172h5MCfwWH37xLRk5ZQY967MXJamCeuT-NRoy3vsigWYeeNX6nAGsEkFYhXwxEln7chNx2N-YRKWzJWMzkEw~yM7T4iV0IjOH--SdKYrAJFKodKm~Ab4F8RiEMrtHqMPfBRiJNDLsFrahvgit5T-04czS4vuV3NrKFVMLvP3R2e0dALHb7-rSaBMQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0104\u22125341. The 1D spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in both R400 spectra near an observed wavelength of \u223c8319 \u00c5. Both images are oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755929/staa200fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755929\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=Zn3hKBKR3hx4s6Z5NqeOdILCcWk6Vh2qpukUoE859nfdIaHk34qCyxUZZjzIF5VHVLeDaIDepuMRXE9ZiL6FcZL6aIP2WtuSn9pvtpgtZkoMhLyvJDqoIIjQQ5l80ZSMopcix9H~uf74N5qFoFK1V67wnMrQjryJG1JfhnR1V9B7gbNAYMJtUwSUkY1m8lMtAQf7Ca0nscQKlRydzxa7zkn0ce6B8E~4nwKjLpi0tzWWzHE4QkCfhwolpfe89F9e9Ax3fKZn3HUEheCRik8PaWP9-AlDKQLmu8VDeK9ekbUdyipb6OGFj0f3~7baoYv0jSYGaUE7jLLjaCjixC1ItQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755929&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0104\u22125341. The 1D spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown on the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in both <em>R400</em> spectra near an observed wavelength of \u223c8319 \u00c5. We associate this feature with [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], which yields redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 in A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, and the scale bar shows the size of the image. In the lower right-hand panel is an identical colour co-add image. Both images are oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6500\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0259 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 2.18\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.43\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(2.42 \\pm 1.10) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755931 id=\"201755931\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 DES J0120\u22125143</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The central red galaxy of this group-scale system, DES J0120\u22125143, has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6030\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0630. There exist three source images, A1, A2, and A3, to the east, north-east, and north\u2013north-west, respectively, of the central red galaxy in the image, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(c)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. In all <em>R400</em> data (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, left-hand panel), there are emission-line features near \u223c8557 \u00c5, which we attribute to [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. The resulting redshifts for the source images are <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for arcs A1, A2, and A3, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"201755933\" scrollto-destination=\"201755933\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=fQiXar4EWGZzpwqQUX26TYsZqBlPMXYS0zP503Wu20p3glYmjAm~bkpcVc3HUGxAsRF9uHFldcmNNlL4PWH~DMWDP4ZjmHlyB7ss5C3p8qaB8q8GJZm7PAEj~qWj~KJm3Ut-Kvavg9UEmm2syP2rjv~Vc8~FELmCR7jYMfxRlpGILeqQLzsGC~0rjblcMK43ZLsAUa50thJd094KbrZIhRbF8IS-YerbTlNdiji3vvjfWz8szqIZBa0yy0AhzN7tPQzLRck9XuXFuESiz8wotcaDDfXYrVRjnOt8ZFmDLO~x4Bh3~JnLv~REdX51Lw9Qmx9jk2vO-ODTpxN-G9mixw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0120\u22125143. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in all three R400 spectra near \u223c8556 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009ii], and from which we obtain redshifts zsource = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. There are emission lines in all three <em>R400</em> spectra near \u223c8556 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], and from which we obtain redshifts <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2955\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0000, and 1.2957\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0005 for A1, A2, and A3, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, the three features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019, \u2018A2\u2019, and \u2018A3\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This lensing system resides in a group environment. There is a counter-image at the south-west that lies nearly on top of the central red lensing galaxy. We were not able to target it for follow-up spectroscopic observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.5238\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0173 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 3.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.51\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(4.46 \\pm 2.78) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755936 id=\"201755936\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 DES J0227\u22124516</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0227\u22124516 is a group-scale lens with the DES photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4300\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0400 and one blue knot (A1) to the south. The system is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(i)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Near wavelengths \u223c 8396 \u00c5, we identify an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line in the <em>R400</em> spectra of the blue knot. This yields source redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.252\u200964\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.000\u200909 (A1) (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, left-hand panel). We used the data from 2016 December to do the redshift determination, because the seeing was much better. We also targeted the faint arc to the east, but the signal-to-noise ratio of the data was too low, and we could not obtain a redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"201755938\" scrollto-destination=\"201755938\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=pvNl-fyCaXDNq1Kzb1K7nsJ3-kXeEnNHo-paP7p1WYbjkHtka6iAav8szou0KOOaIMRXn~LpB4U2Mlt1Oc2ExMHKBj6aRX-8XRnUIa9g7htiX2lPm4YG8A9kUgaOq2YKh63mEGrt3fL~suATR9p1eS~tYbFD8tWhLRE7IL~52dZJpr7eaMoSl6h86afj52qOJwKzz9I9iey63wAjWolzHR3Q1kQOrlmuaVuixgOAgk7rMR5jxPfK5xs-0eMWgaWIYChaa-WzYknqytQ33iLLHAbj0r5KTFUOvz4X7US1zc95ioIZvzxl56aGlcKnGcfd6uWaGNR~Jxo3KVtWpoBKHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0227\u22124516. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour co-add image in the right-hand panel, the feature of interest is labelled \u2018A1\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4347\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0183 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 4.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.28\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(4.32 \\pm 1.32) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755940 id=\"201755940\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-5>5.5 DES J0357\u22124756</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0357\u22124756 is a cluster-scale lens, where the central lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.2570\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240. There is a red arc (A1) to the west, a large red arc (A2) to the south-west, and a red arc (A3) to the south, respectively, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(d)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. In the follow-up <em>R400</em> spectroscopy of all three arcs (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, left-hand panels), we identify an emission line at \u223c7141 \u00c5, which we identify as [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. From this emission line, we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"201755942\" scrollto-destination=\"201755942\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=FYEbWglwK3S6qyOEY4qXvWJuOlqu~5m9CsbzpsZ07yI9pslCTacbGWDIYHhIwfD5c4yP7LDn8-qwTwIWSK-Xyx8Ki46hScgRqR0Oe5CTRKg60srvoWakNID~3ZFzhfNfY6NjAfHNpEkvCRVaNFkAhK9E6JzBq79LXe2ASPgGPQxzU7IGlOPSpqIrAb1xCHdGm8NDUi-wDlxT2tgPn5tp9kNQlYmzRiQk4IzoDX0eYUqP9f4Fb2DUcEeCPr92ZY2TbLsF0VOIEJmVuLDKdIv5tNKAJVwrkXfZhLosl28AaLxXeFw~cFBw-PVvS5anNW2EaKFAQppQHK-peY2RPcUBiA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0357\u22124756. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. Near the observed wavelength of \u223c7142 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009ii] in all three R400 spectra, from which we obtain redshifts of zsource = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, for A1, A2, and A3, respectively, and which are labelled in the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. The image is oriented north up, east left. The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the position designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images to extract the Einstein radius and lens mass.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755942/staa200fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755942\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=vLQH1hf~5hwAJW0jZBWXGerv9lSClCHCIFM726AWGjBZShsjFdWzYM0e9Fu1~HuG6GokDA4ZQjoc1Z6Ui~e-pQbiVKQOPA6yp4r1seT1T3ngtn~knvD4E8AosbI-qJCIuRj~5qx71HDCbN40svN7ypqBv2BRWGoSmhviBlJjVjBkO3lZ1vR-GRKKX6QV2DQElJSo2J~qBNS5uMbMYku4Vun3XM1u4ElJJ3iPiAPJAbogVE9MUcMU85K8grSPaRNjDYp2SSrHkUZHJR9GvfQWbNE7QtpczMweK3hapIpImJIJGwQNwe4cQEPu0D1Gl8h4UsTxJxX7iJNmbTgzwkE2Tw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755942&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0357\u22124756. The 1D spectra for source images A1, A2, and A3 are shown in the left-hand panels. Near the observed wavelength of \u223c7142 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] in all three <em>R400</em> spectra, from which we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, 0.9156\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, and 0.9155\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001, for A1, A2, and A3, respectively, and which are labelled in the colour co-add image in the top right-hand panel, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. The image is oriented north up, east left. The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the position designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images to extract the Einstein radius and lens mass.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The red \u2018x\u2019 near the centre of the colour image in the upper right-hand panel marks the location of the lens designated for the measurement of the Einstein radius. The position of the red \u2018x\u2019 is chosen to simplify the drawing of a circle through the arcs of the source galaxy images. Because the goal is to obtain a simple estimate of the lens mass, our goal is to first obtain a reasonable estimate of the Einstein radius.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.2755\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0129 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 9.39\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.91arcsec\u2009to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.38 \\pm 0.36) \\times 10^{13}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755945 id=\"201755945\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-6>5.6 DES J0418\u22125457</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0418\u22125457 is a galaxy-scale lens with the DES photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6130\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0430 and one blue arc (A1) to the north. The system is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(h)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Near a wavelength of \u223c9030 \u00c5, we identify an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line in the <em>R400</em> spectra of both arcs. This yields a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.4236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 (A1) (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, left-hand panel).</p>                        <a id=\"201755947\" scrollto-destination=\"201755947\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=1CA-AMc~FDKNNmDmHKNy0miG-njobXCDSQUB6oOogqSLTWxBNJyQRVdp84Kicxm-kLwi3bO~MGEAIg6nUW9TZz-UdhUgGiaEHh1s69WANB5hUmySobMsdTncPm1iAr86HOeHIKxKVyiTs0WbInmwH8w0-5nP~6a9Vxnf6X4CEv7FxzyMTTdt0mTqGuwSraqutTkkceIg-Q-y6r7zSAQZEOhHlrKkRzeF-inA4-4mRp2JFRafB1whOPn9ioOipbG-o4GE7YD0sxmYlOBCmA8YriUGe2bfDFgK2sJqBhkJ5lsw0VhWGdH5OttCmTc15O1wlPbk4QZF7cCRg6sJKbl-TA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J0418\u22125457.
