The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6130\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0430 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 1.97\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.47 \\pm 0.65) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755949 id=\"201755949\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-7>5.7 DES J2113\u22120114</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2113\u22120114 is a galaxy-scale system with two small source images, A1 and A2, which lie to the south-west of the central red galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(e)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4060\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0710. In the <em>R400</em> spectra for A1, we identify emission-line features near \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7361, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5. In both images, we take these emission lines to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 4959, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 5006, respectively, from which we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) for these source images.</p>                        <a id=\"201755951\" scrollto-destination=\"201755951\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=Bv9QpQZPInfytNnAL10dBvJ64RmXQ9mMAoft5yp47fiSaSMVJn41FejWSuxSf0IJd1L3LF0Q9hPOKgZ2ua2YgYu~Ca44X-66Y5SRTTZLDluIqQvoo5DK37lyk1NNMysn9qlPkTyCnn7zv4XjhbZXlhjlvSoCD8TeNqtsgTqx52t4z1frZFmdN8MJOJ94lhosSKrh~ia1PQVjsLERE6eyBu2X1~Exqd82gu20pcJ6xM83cy2k3U2i-lbf2YBA-h1MHZGdgZHpIMx~4fJz4nosoH5NQAGi9WCyAjpXTsZZR-n52E7fbhB5dmccAZetsXNV03~bPzBy4Ub9pFIQPIZmVw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2113\u22120114. The 1D R400 spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. A1 presents emission lines near observed wavelengths of \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5, which we conclude correspond to [O\u2009ii], [Ne\u2009iii] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009iii] 4959, and [O\u2009iii]5006, respectively. From these emission lines, we obtain redshifts of zsource = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A2. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755951/staa200fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755951\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=CZEl56OV1H0douKmdvbaGacCUHy0o1o1tEs98Se9QIkUb-sWVQXWjHO8qvwBlSBdSUAV4fqrCWUyKoYcLRdxL0orgO83BCjk~ur9jylhf7sL0FlP5TTIJ~1wUTL6c5Jg9-umjbKijUX4gxFzcjXwr8lnnuIikwIeA6PZN7xvwfKG6FTQqQP4fBZ8mPcB3BvJLCqLTZKpt8MRA985SvTCFna5xuGJipqLkaaFdxCCKMvs4aSsFC5yqMI26-ziagOSNt6DlzKzSzTDcoUhxH4~NJ1Eicrq4WlKMYaWjkkHWPNb7g6nLJjMPlKKqXyYNQCKSZNh6UiSpN3ewADVExzjMQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755951&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2113\u22120114. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for source images A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. A1 presents emission lines near observed wavelengths of \u223c6689, \u223c6942, \u223c7790, \u223c8723, \u223c8898, and \u223c8984 \u00c5, which we conclude correspond to [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 3869, H\u03b4, H\u03b3, H\u03b2, [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 4959, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]5006, respectively. From these emission lines, we obtain redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 0.7943\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A1 and 0.7947\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0002 for A2. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019, along with a scale bar to show the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4472\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0187 and the estimated source image\u2212lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 1.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.51\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(1.28 \\pm 1.06) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755953 id=\"201755953\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-8>5.8 DES J2321\u22124630</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2321\u22124630 is a group-scale lens with two central galaxies with DESDM photometric redshifts <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6440\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0250 and 0.70\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02. There are two small red arcs, A1 and A2, to the east and north-east, respectively, of the central red galaxy. These are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(f)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The <em>R400</em> spectrum of A1 shows prominent emission lines near five different observed wavelengths: \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5, which we identify as C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>] 3346, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], respectively. This gives a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7469\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0014. The <em>R400</em> spectrum of A2 presents a similar pattern for these emission lines: \u223c6391, \u223c6661, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5, which yields a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7479\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0031 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, left-hand panel). There is a possible counter-image to the south-southwest of the lensing galaxy, but it could not be targeted due to its proximity to the central red galaxy and available telescope time.</p>                        <a id=\"201755955\" scrollto-destination=\"201755955\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=FzjbnDTMO-aeRoNyf0Pw-eWLtQFuXxjiex~mUNigqdem4u-AQFG4k9xTo1djglyaUdmHtILN0SWGF1QLpqFqrt2ImSiKg2XungO1xh2hUpQ2RM~QKIIdUT4KYBOe4eqB4YK9ZI~M7lGMjZQg3do3BKqulYEtHrReTxBv-iz15TP~25bQ3EopVJv0kVdAgadVO6OD5BZPA~vikiy~1dKLsDDW7URHoSOwjxVLI1Ae6NU~Gq57OVQOGIz2vUVKeDjKMcbJb9PDgXj3gIITyhEmvLhyg~Yvi8c07SMecJHlcaNYKyo3eimyUWksNeq6RL4SS9OglmAcJHNVdkEOwVql2Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2321\u22124630. The emission lines at four different observed wavelengths in A1 at \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5 are due to C\u2009ii] 2326, [Ne\u2009iv] 2424, and [O\u2009ii], respectively. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for sources A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The emission lines at four different observed wavelengths in A1 at \u223c6385, \u223c6658, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5 are due to C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 2326, [Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 2424, and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], respectively. A similar pattern of emission lines occurs in A2 at \u223c6391, \u223c6661, \u223c9413, and \u223c10\u2009242 \u00c5. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.7469\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0014 and 1.7479\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0031 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presence of the Ne emission lines in combination with O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines suggests the possibility that the source is a radio galaxy. Humphrey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) identifies Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> and Ne\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission in <em>z</em>\u223c 2.5 radio galaxies as a potential signature of active galactic nucleus photoionization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The two central galaxies are found in the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> catalogue with redshifts <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6244\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240 and 0.6244\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0240. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaGiC</span> redshifts and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 3.30\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.74\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(3.84 \\pm 1.87) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201755958 id=\"201755958\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-9>5.9 DES J2349\u22125113</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113 is a group-scale lens. The central galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.3450\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0320, and there are two blue arcs (A1 and A2) to the east and the west. These are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(g)</a> and in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. Near wavelengths of \u223c8920 \u00c5, we identify [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission lines in the <em>R400</em> spectra of both arcs. These yield source redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, left-hand panel). Only after sky subtraction was the line in A2 revealed. Note that A2 appears more extended and much fainter than A1, and, thus, has a much lower signal-to-noise ratio. The faintness of the source, along with a sky line on top of the data (which affected the subtraction), likely reduced the signal in this emission line. The low signal-to-noise ratio for A2 likely contributes to an error in redshift that causes the spectroscopic redshifts to differ beyond their estimated errors.</p>                        <a id=\"201755960\" scrollto-destination=\"201755960\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/m_staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&amp;Signature=uVdyIe-B0vL4vKe4wOuOGPel3Cocxl4deY9iNjg4nQYpMDV8Yw7f01v2kvW-Vl~HFGbpSrOIghJ24kj83qKo6hR1AQ8Ytz-REdGJ6bgiFE7GVgjNIPR~etd7JBxIH0vLEVmntxcpYkXPt1nX4EC~XXTmwD3vVIFvHIPJ8MT-KNCuNAGcnjylEJjZkOQ2moSP5ofWoFbMLPsrMhSfwyrzJfpHDOfTDsIEPDOTrtJBxKRx8LSugGEeYN4crT8D~Ve8s38JqzZWP-oDyuaU5FmskaTcdio0qTFlJiYkfMvOGlwi8NuBXKInWdBHW71arU-MNoHXawR~WQNwJxcnxtEmnQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"DES J2349\u22125113. The 1D R400 spectra for A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009ii]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of zsource = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the iraf task splot. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755960/staa200fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=3wqA6Hnh3H7ok0flLyOL0RE5bpls2UQE9DlgXq0chx0uP40UkJitq25xH8kgRbAjgp-t5FtNL3oVDablM2DS-~8Ph5m9H7IdDN1JaihilI4MD979VQyVY1zFUeZ2nrAl2eiWUHM~~0ZmktZE3euGk-Ndv0PZRK5u5kYmtZw1h5Jeb0bls0OK7QjTdGctQOClhGkcmZ496JckxT8IJWm236X4lnHfTf3I7fqZApV5MKnyJyG1OQVJ~rFHX709eFnD2E5tnWjQ2VVoN2ScrlvPK3FaZhrrU-ex7y-Zc8j1o43Ur5T4pPJopfKtfd-UDqesEZ1wqOXy6qbo7MeI9Ox6xA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755960&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of zsource = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201755960/staa200fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201755960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/1/10.1093_mnras_staa200/1/staa200fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611454428&Signature=3wqA6Hnh3H7ok0flLyOL0RE5bpls2UQE9DlgXq0chx0uP40UkJitq25xH8kgRbAjgp-t5FtNL3oVDablM2DS-~8Ph5m9H7IdDN1JaihilI4MD979VQyVY1zFUeZ2nrAl2eiWUHM~~0ZmktZE3euGk-Ndv0PZRK5u5kYmtZw1h5Jeb0bls0OK7QjTdGctQOClhGkcmZ496JckxT8IJWm236X4lnHfTf3I7fqZApV5MKnyJyG1OQVJ~rFHX709eFnD2E5tnWjQ2VVoN2ScrlvPK3FaZhrrU-ex7y-Zc8j1o43Ur5T4pPJopfKtfd-UDqesEZ1wqOXy6qbo7MeI9Ox6xA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201755960&ar=5716698&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa200fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">DES J2349\u22125113. The 1D <em>R400</em> spectra for A1 and A2 are shown in the left-hand panels. The prominent emission lines near observed wavelengths \u223c 8920 \u00c5 are considered to be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. These lines yield source spectroscopic redshifts of <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.3932\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.3938\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. The spectra are smoothed using a boxcar with a width of 5 pixels with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task <span class=\"monospace\">splot</span>. In the colour coadded image in the top right-hand panel, the two features of interest are labelled \u2018A1\u2019 and \u2018A2\u2019. The scale bar shows the size of the image. The image is oriented north up, east left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">redMaPPer</span> redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.4094\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0189 and the estimated source image\u2013lens separation of <em>\u03b8</em><sub>sep</sub> = 4.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.71\u2009arcsec to calculate an enclosed mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm enc}=(3.77 \\pm 1.42) \\times 10^{12}\\, {\\rm M_{\\odot }}$|</span> for this system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755962 id=\"201755962\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION AND SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented new confirmations of galaxy- to cluster-scale strong lenses in Y1 DES data. We first identified candidates in DES data through an investigation of cluster sub-samples, and through catalogue searches of galaxies based on the photometry and proximity of lenses and source images. We then visually inspected these sub-samples to identify 46 candidates for a spectroscopic follow-up. The search was conducted over 1800 deg<sup>2</sup>. We confirmed these systems with spectroscopy from GMOS on the Gemini South telescope. The confirmed sample comprises three galaxy-scale lenses, five group-scale lenses, and one cluster-scale lens. They have been identified through known emission lines, such as Ly\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${}[{\\rm O\\,{\\small II}}]$|</span> 3727. Of particular note is one system, DES J2321\u22124630, in which the presence of Ne emission lines suggests it may be a radio galaxy. For all the confirmed lenses, we provide a rough estimate of the lens mass based on an average of the source image\u2013lens separation from <em>Diehl17</em>. Detailed modelling of these systems can contribute to studies of mass profiles and mass-to-light ratios of early-type galaxies. Poh et\u00a0al. (in preparation) will report the modelling of a subset of these confirmed systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift desert is a key problem in the spectroscopic follow-up of strong lenses. A number of our candidates could not be confirmed or rejected, because they may exist in a redshift range not covered by GMOS spectrographs. One possible solution to this challenge is to seek improved photometric redshift estimations of high-redshift source galaxies. The measurement or prediction of photometric redshifts of distance objects is itself a long-time challenge, largely due to the small number of training sets at high redshift. Another solution is to perform observations in a higher wavelength range \u2013 e.g. in the (near-)infrared with Gemini South\u2019s FLAMINGOS-2 instrument<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> and Paranal Observatory\u2019s Very Large Telescope, which has MUSE and X-Shooter.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The search in DES Y1 data and in that of Nord et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) produced many more candidates than feasibly can be followed up with modern spectroscopic observation resources. We confirmed fewer than of those we observed, with an observational strategy that efficiently used the available observing time. The best way to improve chances of positive spectroscopic confirmation in future work is to more accurately and precisely predict strong lens candidates from their imaging. Future searches of DES data are set to take place with more advanced algorithms, stemming from machine learning and citizen science programmes, among others. We expect that these algorithms will provide more flexibility, power, and efficiency in identifying high-quality strong lens candidates.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201755966 id=\"201755966\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We are grateful for the extraordinary contributions of our CTIO colleagues and the DES Camera, Commissioning, and Science Verification teams for achieving excellent instrument and telescope conditions that have made this work possible. The success of this project also relies critically on the expertise and dedication of the DES Data Management organization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Kavli Institute of Cosmological Physics at the University of Chicago, the Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics at the Ohio State University, the Mitchell Institute for Fundamental Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&amp;M University, Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos, Funda\u00e7\u00e3o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo \u00e0 Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cient\u00edfico e Tecnol\u00f3gico and the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia e Tecnologia, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, and the Collaborating Institutions in the DES. The DES data management system is supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant Number AST-1138766. The DES participants from Spanish institutions are partially supported by MINECO under grants AYA2012-39559, ESP2013-48274, FPA2013-47986, and Centro de Excelencia Severo Ochoa SEV-2012-0234, some of which include ERDF funds from the European Union.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne National Laboratory, the University of California at Santa Cruz, the University of Cambridge, Centro de Investigaciones Energ\u00e9ticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas-Madrid, the University of Chicago, University College London, the DES-Brazil Consortium, the Eidgenoessische Technische Hochschule (ETH) Zurich, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the University of Edinburgh, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Institut de Ci\u00e8ncies de l\u2019Espai (IEEC/CSIC), the Institut de F\u00edsica d\u2019Altes Energies, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the Ludwig-Maximilians Universit\u00e4t and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, the University of Michigan, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, the University of Nottingham, the Ohio State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Portsmouth, the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, the University of Sussex, and Texas A&amp;M University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work is based in part on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), the Australian Research Council (Australia), Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (Brazil), and Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog\u00eda e Innovaci\u00f3n Productiva (Argentina). The data were processed using the Gemini <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> package v2.16.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This research has made use of NASA\u2019s Astrophysics Data System.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This manuscript has been authored by Fermi Research Alliance, LLC under Contract No. DE-AC02-07CH11359 with the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Office of High Energy Physics. The United States Government retains and the publisher, by accepting the article for publication, acknowledges that the United States Government retains a non-exclusive, paid-up, irrevocable, worldwide license to publish or reproduce the published form of this manuscript, or allow others to do so, for United States Government purposes.</p>                    <h2 "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">DES J0104\u22125341 is a galaxy-scale lensing system. The red lensing galaxy has a photometric redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub> = 0.6790\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0220, and there are two relatively red arcs to the west and south, labelled A1 and A2, respectively, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1(b)</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We identify strong emission lines for A1 and A2 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, left-hand panel) in both <em>R400</em> spectra near an observed wavelength of \u223c8319 \u00c5. In the absence of features in the <em>B600</em> spectra, we associate this feature with [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], yielding redshifts <em>z</em><sub>source</sub> = 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 and 1.2318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001 for A1 and A2, respectively. We see no counter-images for this source."}, "Status": "Complete", "Link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2020MNRAS.494.1308N/PUB_HTML", "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Action": "Processed via pandas", "Status": "Complete", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Cluster Sources Table": "", "Follow up table": "", "Word to recognize name is of lens and NOT source": "DES"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"Dec [\u00b0]": "('Dec. C.", "Tarle, G.", "Thomas, D.", "Zhang, Y.", "DES Collaboration"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "abstract": "We describe the observation and confirmation of nine new strong gravitational lenses discovered in Year 1 data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES). We created candidate lists based on (I) galaxy group and cluster samples, and (II) photometrically selected galaxy samples. We selected 46 candidates through visual inspection and then used the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph(GMOS) at the Gemini South telescope to acquire a spectroscopic follow-up of 21 of these candidates. Through an analysis of these spectroscopic follow-up data, we confirmed nine new lensing systems and rejected two candidates, and the analysis was inconclusive on 10 candidates. For each of the confirmed systems, our report measured spectroscopic properties, estimated source image-lens separations, and estimated enclosed masses as well. The sources that we targeted have an I-band surface brightness range of and a spectroscopic redshift range of z<SUB>spec</SUB> \u223c 0.8-2.6. The lens galaxies have a photometric redshift range of z<SUB>lens</SUB> \u223c 0.3-0.7. The lensing systems range in source image-lens separation from 2 to 9 arcsec and in enclosed mass from 10<SUP>12</SUP> to 10<SUP>13</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB>.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/staa200", "start_page": "1308", "number": "1", "publication_year": "2020/01/1", "end_page": "1322", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1911.02162", "author_address": ["AA(Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, PO Box 500, Batavia, IL 60510, USA;
